Joe Eagar But instead, we got a bunch of nihilistic "civil rights" narcissists, who invoke Dr. King's name even as they do everything they can to undermine the success of his vision.  I've said it before: America's civil rights model doesn't work.  Just look at the data.  And the reason it doesn't work is because we've turned away from Dr. King's words.

Joe Eagar If Dr. King had survived, America would not be nearly as messed up as it is today.  He would worked towards a high social trust America, where people of different races would live together in peace.  I really think the man could have done it, too; and that would have been an accomplishment for the whole world.

Joe Eagar Why are we celebrating Dr. King's "I Have A Dream" speech?  His vision of race relations is politically incorrect these days (he advocated a melting pot approach, not a "salad bowl.").  I don't see why we should let our elites get away with praising that man and using his name, when they don't even believe in his message.

with all due respect you forget the house republicans adamantly oppose any legalization at all, and are calling senate republicans who supported it traitors, even Marco Rubio.

Tell, the Tea Party opposes legalization, not House Republicans as a whole.  The politics there is complicated, but a true enforcement-first bill could pass.  The major issue is broken trust: the government passed a law almost identical to this in 1987, but the border security measures never happened.  It's all about credibility.

Matt, I'm rather squishy on this issue, actually.  I support either a) massively increased skilled immigration, or b) less unskilled immigration.  Both would fix a lot of problems in our economy and our society.  I don't really care which one happens.

description: Joe Eagar How's this for immigration reform: why not pass a bill that legalized the undocumented after the border has been proven secure, but rather than have a lengthy eight or ten year waiting period, have it be *three* years?  (if the border is proven secure after three years, legalization can begin).  Immigration's greatest foe has always been the Democrats, who see the issue as a crude way to divide whites and Hispanics, not something they actually want to see happen (which risks dividing *blacks* and Hispanics).  It's entirely a racial issue for them; that's why they killed the reform process in 2007, and that's why they're killing it in 2013.  But such racial tactics are a double-edge sword: if an enforcement-first bill passed the House with a short, three-year legalization timeframe, just imagine the pressure Senate Democrats would come under from Hispanic groups.  The Democrats perpetually promise open borders and redistribution of wealth, yet it never happens.  On the other hand, if the Republicans were able to deliver legalization for those already here, *in a shorter timeframe than the Democrat's plan*. . .

comments.content: What do you think would be a decent minimum wage, or do you think there should be one?

The minimum, by itself, is a fairly useless policy.  It's usefulness is when it's combined with wage subsidies (like the Earned Income  Tax Credit), where it acts as a floor to keep employers (as opposed from employees) from capturing the subsidy.
Thus, how high it should be depends on how high said subsidies are.  Which I don't really have an opinion on.

description: Joe Eagar What's this I hear about a $15 minimum wage?  That's insane.  The experience of Europe is clear; that sort of policy leads to greater social inequality, as the labor market becomes segmented between "labor market insiders" and outside groups (the unemployed, migrant workers, etc).  You end up with a permanently-unemployed class of workers.  It's especially dangerous given America's external financial position.  In the long run, large hikes in the minimum wage lead to inflation, and under floating currencies inflation leads to currency devaluation.  Our trading partners and creditors are already tolerating a fairly large risk of long-term losses on their dollar holdings, given the fiscal deficits of the past five years; something as stupid as doubling the minimum wage could very well panic them.

comments.content: Java was never intended to be a client-side platform for browsers.  The popularity and prevalence of Java created a desire to incorporate Java applets into the browser, which came with a panoply of security vulnerabilities contributing to its subsequen ... See More
Stagnant American programmer productivity?  Java is a huge part of that problem.
And I disagree that Sun was somehow shoehorned into targeting browsers.

Thanks to the wonders of capitalism, if Java were making us less productive, somehow I don't think we'd be using it.  I'm curious as to what you consider a more productive language.  Python?  C++? Sun wasn't shoehorned in to targeting browsers.  They  ... See More
Call me stupid, but in the consultant world people are paid for time and corrections of their own mistakes. Enough reasons for java.  :)
Python and C (not C++ so much) are both more productive and expressive languages than Java, each in their own way.

Neither C nor Python scales to the kinds of problem domains to which Java is most commonly applied (enterprise applications).  C because its lack of object-orientation and weak typing, and Python because of its dynamic typing and the GIL.  Neither lang ... See More

"Scale" is not a word I associate with Java.  In point of fact, you don't need an explicit class system to code in an object-oriented style.  Everyone wishes there was version of C that had a bare-bones class syntax (C++ certainly doesn't cut it).
Java's advantages in its class system, however, is more than outweighed by its disadvantages: too much reliance on GC, an inherently unproductive coding style, etc.

Java seems to scale just fine across thousands of machines at Facebook, Yahoo, etc. with Hadoop.  Distributed filesystem, MapReduce, distributed database: all written in Java.   Too much reliance on GC and an unproductive coding style.  Right, because ... See More
You don't have much experience with C, do you.
Ad hominem in lieu of an argument, great.  Look, believe whatever you want.  Everyone else is mad, Java is nebulously unproductive, C is the best object-oriented language ever made.  Later!
It does happen to be true.

I recently went to a meeting with a group of Arizona tech entrepreneurs.   Every single one of them were outsourcing their programming tasks, and this in a part of the country where the cost of living (and thus labor costs) is low.

We do have a productivity problem with software engineers in America, and I do think Java is a big part of it, given how hard universities pushed it as a "safe" alternative to "horrible" languages like C and C++.

I'm not saying that C is the best language to use, or Python (though I do think C is better than Java).  I'm saying that Java is a piece of crap language that has only survived due to corporate inertia.

Thanks for providing actually providing a point I can respond to.   I agree we have a productivity problem, but I think it's caused by bad programmers, not bad programming languages.  That's a complicated issue that needs to be addressed, but I don't  ... See More

I'm not sure if ObjC/C# are evidence against the corporate inertia theory (one could argue they represent pent-up demand).  Anyway, I look forward to Java's replacement, as well.  Let us all hope it is not JavaScript.  :)
You might have a point there on the productivity end.

Frankly, what each house of Congress does and does not pass has nothing to do with anything; it's all political posturing.  What matters is what *both* houses pass, and Obama signs.

description: Joe Eagar I have the feeling I'm going to find myself calling Politico and arguing with their reporters over this story:   http://www.politico.com/…/…/is-paul-ryan-racist-104687.html…  After the way us policy wonks have had to live with the Democrat's race politics where immigration is concerned (remember that Barack Obama is widely believed to have personally *opposed* comprehensive immigration reform for many years, even helping to defeat it when Bush pushed it in 2007), reading an article about how *horrible* it is that Republicans used *mean race code words* twenty years ago is a little much.  Please, do spend at least a little time reporting on the growing economic conflict between poor whites/blacks and Hispanics that the Democrats are inciting.  Politico has come so close to admitting what is going on (they've mentioned a few times that the Democratic Party is unwilling to accept comprehensive immigration reform, for example).  If it's going to write these annoying, Southern-centric historical pieces on Republican sins, it should write about *current Democratic transgresses*.

Joe Eagar This Guardian piece is really quite amazing.  Any bets on how long until its pulled by the editors?  Seriously, a *central bank* is endorsing reckless fiscal policy?  I just love this line:  "It's this understanding that allows us to continue to talk about money as if it were a limited resource like bauxite or petroleum..."  Money may not be scarce, but bauxite and petroleum are.  Since every bit of government spending requires some amount of petroleum (along with food, land, and all the other stuff that people spend their wages on), there is, in fact, a finite limit to government spending.

description: Joe Eagar I don't understand why liberals fixate over slavery, especially in discussions over reparations.  You would think they would talk about segregation instead, which is not only much more relevant to today's problems (no living black person alive experienced slavery, but plenty of them remember Jim Crow), but the reparations case for segregation is actually much stronger than for slavery (given how many white people died to end it).  My own theory is that this is a cultural holdover from the days when liberal Democrats included a lot of white supremacists in their ranks.  I imagine race liberals found it much easier to blame black problems on slavery then segregation in the Southern-dominated 70s-era Democratic Party.

comments.content: what do you mean by ethnic corporatism?

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corporatism , basically the rule of identity politics (which used to be called corporate politics).  Most corporatist countries in the world today are based on profession and class; the general idea is that layers, sanitation workers, engineers, etc as well as the working, middle, and upper classes bargain with each other over the distribution of resources.

Ethnic corporatism is the same idea, only applied to ethnic groups.  When liberals talk about "minority-majority", they're talking about ethnic corporatism.  Exactly why they think it would work here when it's failed so spectacularly in the EU (especially where Germany and the Mediterranian states are concerned) is beyond me.

Joe Eagar Heh, if you want to utterly destroy the Northeastern Puritan school of American ethnic factionalism (aka "Democratic Identity Politics"), get CA to try and secede.  Of course, that assumes America wouldn't simply go the way of the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

Joe Eagar There are lots of little signs the wealthier areas in CA are probably in balance of payments deficit (they borrow/import more than they produce/export).  Wages are both too high in nominal terms for CA to be competitive, but too low in real terms when adjusted for the price level, a classic sign of regional balance of payments dysfunction within a fixed currency area.  One of the consequences of this is an outflow of skilled labor.  My older brother has turned down jobs in the San Francisco Bay Area because, after adjusting for the cost of living, he'd take a pretty hefty wage cut.  This is especially bad for Silicon Valley, which relies on skilled labor.  Think of it this way: employees cost Facebook twice as much in CA as they would in, say, Texas, *and those employee's wage are also lower in real terms.*  Not good.

Joe Eagar Nothing is more embarrassing then the American news media.  Sometimes I wish the government would just shut it all down; conservative, liberal, centrist alike, exile the entire workforce and then let the industry rebuild itself from scratch.

comments.content: Finland. Universal health care is not only about forcing people to pay for their own care. In Finland it is about building a system that invests in health care such that all who need it can receive it. Ensuring availability to the whole population mak ... See More

description: Joe Eagar Americans have the wrong idea about universal healthcare.  We tend to think of Britain and Canada.  Britain especially presents the NHS as a right.  This is not how many other Europeans view healthcare, who often pay for it more directly (e.g. through municipal taxation (Finnland), mandated insurance policies (Switzerland/Netherlands), etc).  The whole point of universal healthcare is to force people to pay for their own care, not give it to them for free (remember when people would routinely visit ER's and then skip out on the bill?).

Joe Eagar  commented on an article. So, in 2015 co2 levels jumped? That stretches credulity.  None of the big emitters were growing fast enough for that, except perhaps for America where emissions fell.  No matter how loud they scream, the alarmists can't overcome the fact that there simply isn't any danger of short term climate catastrophe. The warming so far just isn't that much, .8 celsius (that's over two hundred years). Most of the warming hasn't happened yet.
